org.strongback.control

Class SoftwarePIDController

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.strongback.control.SoftwarePIDController
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    LiveWindowSendable, Sendable, Requirable, Controller, PIDController

    @ThreadSafe
public class SoftwarePIDController
extends Object
implements LiveWindowSendable, PIDController
    A software-only Proportional Integral Differential (PID) controller with optional support for feed forward. The source of inputs and the output to which results are written are both supplied as functions upon construction.

    There are two ways to use this controller:

    1. Manually - a controller instance is used within or as a subsystem, but it is only run when it is used by commands. The controller's target, tolerance, and other settings are typically modified , typically with commands.
    2. With commands - a controller instance is used within or as a subsystem, and one or more command classes are created to use this by setting the setpoint (and optionally the gains, input and output ranges, and tolerance) and calling computeOutput(); or
    3. Continuous execution - a controller instance is registered with an Executor (typically Strongback's built-in executor) to continuously execute and generate the output based upon the input and current setpoint. The setpoint, gains, input and output ranges, and tolerance can all be changed at any time, including.

    Recording data

    It is possible to register a PIDController with a DataRecordable to record separate channels for this controller's instantaneous values used. To record the input, output, setpoint, and error values on separate channels, simply register this controller's simple DataRecordable: 
     SoftwarePIDController controller = ...
 DataRecorder recorder = ...
 recorder.register("Azimuth Control", controller.basicChannels());
    To record these channels plus the individual error components, register the following instead: 
     recorder.register("Azimuth Control", controller.errorChannels());
    Or, to record all detailed channels, register the following instead: 
     recorder.register("Azimuth Control", controller.detailedChannels());

    Profiles

    Each SoftwarePIDController instance is able to have 1 or more independent sets of PID gains, called profiles . One of these profiles is always in use, and by default it is the "default" profile. Additional profiles can be defined, and then while in operation the gains for the controller can be switched to any of the named profiles.

    • Constructor Detail

      • SoftwarePIDController

        public SoftwarePIDController(Supplier<SoftwarePIDController.SourceType> sourceType,
                             DoubleSupplier source,
                             DoubleConsumer output)
        Create a new PID+FF controller that uses the supplied source for inputs and sends outputs to the supplied consumer. Before using, be sure to set the PID and feed forward gains, the input range, output range, setpoint, tolerance, and whether the inputs are continuous (e.g., they wrap around continuously).
        Parameters:
        sourceType - the type of source values; may not be null
        source - the source from which the inputs are to be read; may not be null
        output - the output to which the calculated output is to be send; may not be null

      • SoftwarePIDController

        public SoftwarePIDController(SoftwarePIDController.SourceType sourceType,
                             DoubleSupplier source,
                             DoubleConsumer output)
        Create a new PID+FF controller that uses the supplied source for inputs and sends outputs to the supplied consumer. Before using, be sure to set the PID and feed forward gains, the input range, output range, setpoint, tolerance, and whether the inputs are continuous (e.g., they wrap around continuously).
        Parameters:
        sourceType - the type of source values; may not be null
        source - the source from which the inputs are to be read; may not be null
        output - the output to which the calculated output is to be send; may not be null

    • Method Detail

      • executable

        public Executable executable()
        Get the Executable instance that will continuously execute this controller to read inputs from the source and generate outputs to reach the setpoint.

        If this is used, then this same controller should never be used with commands. This is not checked, so robot programs are responsible for ensuring this does not happen.

        Specified by:
        executable in interface Controller
        Returns:
        the Executable object that can be registered with an Executor (typically Strongback's central executor); never null and always the same instance for this controller

                                         double p,
                                         double i,
                                         double d)
        Description copied from interface: PIDController
        Set the control gains for the specified profile, which may or may not be the current profile. Profile numbers start from 0 and can include any integers, although consecutive non-zero numbers are encouraged. The default profile is 0.
        Specified by:
        withProfile in interface PIDController
        Parameters:
        profile - the profile number; a new profile will be created if a profile with the number does not exist may be an existing or new profile
        p - the proportional gain
        i - the integral gain
        d - the differential gain
        Returns:
        this object so that methods can be chained; never null

      • continuousInputs

        public SoftwarePIDController continuousInputs(boolean continuous)
        Sets whether the input range is continuous, meaning it wraps around such as with an encoder.
        Parameters:
        continuous - true if the input values are continuous values, and if the controller can take into account the error between the actual source and the input values; or false if the controller should calculate the shortest route
        Returns:
        this object so that methods can be chained; never null
        See Also:
        withInputRange(double, double)

      • withInputRange

        public SoftwarePIDController withInputRange(double minimumInput,
                                            double maximumInput)
        Sets the maximum and minimum values expected from the input and setpoint.
        Parameters:
        minimumInput - the minimum value expected from the input
        maximumInput - the maximum value expected from the input
        Returns:
        this object so that methods can be chained; never null
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the minimum is greater than the maximum
        See Also:
        withTarget(double), continuousInputs(boolean)

      • withTarget

        public SoftwarePIDController withTarget(double setpoint)
        Sets the target value for this controller. The input range should be set prior to this call, and the setpoint value should be within the input range values; otherwise, the setpoint will be capped to be within the input range.
        Specified by:
        withTarget in interface Controller
        Specified by:
        withTarget in interface PIDController
        Parameters:

        Returns:
        this object so that methods can be chained; never null

      • computeOutput

        public boolean computeOutput()
        Description copied from interface: Controller
        Calculate the next controller output. This usually involves reading one or more inputs and computing the output based upon a model of the system.
        Specified by:
        computeOutput in interface Controller
        Returns:
        true if the execution completed because it resulted in a value that is within the tolerance of the setpoint, or false if this controller is not enabled or has not yet reached the setpoint given the tolerance

      • basicChannels

        public DataRecordable basicChannels()
        Get a recordable object that can be used to register this controller's input, output, setpoint, and error values as separate channels.
        Returns:
        the recordable object; never null
        See Also:
        errorChannels(), detailedChannels()

      • errorChannels

        public DataRecordable errorChannels()
        Get a recordable object that can be used to register multiple channels for this controller. The channels include:
        • input values
        • output values
        • setpoint values
        • error values
        • proportional error values
        • integral error values
        • differential error values
        • feed forward error values
        Returns:
        the recordable object; never null
        See Also:
        basicChannels(), detailedChannels()

      • detailedChannels

        public DataRecordable detailedChannels()
        Get a recordable object that can be used to register multiple channels for this controller. The channels include:
        • input values
        • output values
        • setpoint values
        • tolerance values
        • error values
        • proportional error values
        • integral error values
        • differential error values
        • feed forward error values
        • total (accumulated) error value
        • proportional gain
        • integral gain
        • differential gain
        • feed forward gain
        Returns:
        the recordable object; never null
        See Also:
        basicChannels(), basicChannels()
